page.title: 16CHARLTON-ON-OTMOOR'S MAY DAY
page.content: Early on May Day morning people in Charlton bring flowers to the School. They are made into bunches and tied onto a Garland.The Garland is made out of seven wire hoops with rope joining them together.The oldest children in the School carry the Garland to the Church.The younger children make crosses decorated with flowers.Walking to the Church they stop to sing the May Garland carol.The Garland is given to the Vicar and hung on the Screen in the Church.The crosses are laid infront of the Screen.After the Service everyone meets outside of the Church for the May Dancing.The children leave the Church and perform Country Dances.The six eldest girls and boys dance around the Maypole.The May Day celebration is a very old tradition and most of the village come to watch.
